To determine if our economy will ever reach a stable point, we need to examine whether the variables in our model will converge or diverge over time.

Let's start with the equation for the growth rate of the economy:

G = go + gg + gf

We know that gg is greater than gf, so we can say that G > go + gf. As long as the growth rates are positive, the economy will continue to grow over time.

Now, let's look at the equations for the prices of green and fossil energy:

pg = (1 + re) \* (1 + G) \* pg(-1)
pf = (1 + rf) \* (1 + G) \* pf(-1)

We know that re > rf, so (1 + re) > (1 + rf). Also, we know that G > 0, so (1 + G) > 1. Therefore, we can say that (1 + re) \* (1 + G) > (1 + rf) \* (1 + G) or (1 + re) \* (1 + G) \* pg(-1) > (1 + rf) \* (1 + G) \* pf(-1).

Assuming that the prices of green and fossil energy in the previous period are positive, we can say that the prices of green and fossil energy will continue to increase over time.

Finally, let's look at the equations for the investments in green and fossil energy:

Ig = ag \* (1 - delta) \* (1 + G) \* Ig(-1) / pg
If = af \* (1 - deltaf) \* (1 + G) \* If(-1) / pf

We know that ag > af, so Ig will grow faster than If over time. As long as the investments are positive and the prices of energy are increasing, the production of green energy will increase faster than the production of fossil energy.

Based on these equations, we can conclude that our economy will not reach a stable point. The growth rates for green and fossil energy and the other sectors in the economy will continue to increase over time, as will the prices of green and fossil energy. However, the growth rate of green energy will be greater than the growth rate of fossil energy, so green energy will become a larger part of the energy mix over time.
